keyTakeAways: A man named Billy Joe Cagle, a 49-year-old convicted felon from Cartersville, Georgia, was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport after a family reported that he had planned to 'shoot it up' the airport via a social media livestream.
Cagle was found in possession of an AR-15 assault rifle and 27 rounds of ammunition in a Chevrolet pickup truck parked outside the airport terminal.
The arrest was enabled by early warning from his family, who alerted law enforcement after seeing his social media posts indicating a plan to carry out violence at the airport.
Cagle was charged with making terroristic threats, criminal attempt to commit aggravated assault, possession of a firearm during the commission of a felony, and possession of a firearm by a felon.
Law enforcement officials emphasized that the incident was averted due to timely intervention, community vigilance, and the use of body camera and surveillance footage.

Cagle had previously disclosed mental health struggles, including schizophrenia and medication use, and had been known in his community as a hardworking individual with strong personal ties to his family.
Federal authorities are investigating how Cagle obtained the firearm, noting that he was not legally allowed to possess one.
The city of Atlanta and federal officials, including Homeland Security Secretary Kristi Noem, praised the successful prevention of a potential mass casualty event.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Billy Joe Cagle, a 49-year-old convicted felon from Cartersville, Georgia, was arrested at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport—world’s busiest airport—after his family alerted police that he had livestreamed a plan to shoot up the facility. Officers found an AR-15 rifle and 27 rounds of ammunition in his Chevrolet pickup truck parked outside the terminal. Cagle, who had previously disclosed struggles with schizophrenia, was charged with making terroristic threats, criminal attempt to commit aggravated assault, and possession of firearms by a felon. The arrest was credited to early warning from family members and community vigilance, with officials emphasizing that a potential mass casualty tragedy was averted. Federal authorities are investigating how Cagle obtained the firearm, which he was not legally allowed to possess. The incident underscores the critical role of personal connections, timely reporting, and public awareness in preventing violent acts in public spaces.
